item.title: The hyperspace of non-cut subcontinua of graphs
item.description: arXiv:2503.18196v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Given a continuum $X$, let $C(X)$ be the hyperspace of all subcontinua of $X$. We consider the hyperspace $NC^{*}(X)=\{A\in C(X):X\setminus A$ is connected$\}$. In this paper we prove that the only locally connected continua $X$ for which $NC^{*}(X)$ is compact are the arcs and the simple closed curves. We also characterize the finite graphs $G$ for which $NC^{*}(G)$ is connected.
item.dc:creator: Alejandro Illanes, Ver\'onica Mart\'inez-de-la-Vega, Jorge E. Vega

item.title: A Minimal Non Hausdorff Counterexample in Covering Space Theory
item.description: arXiv:2506.00031v3 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Classical covering space theory shows that for a connected, locally path connected, semilocally simply connected, and Hausdorff space, there is a perfect correspondence between covering maps and subgroups of its fundamental group. Three key features make the theory work: unique path and homotopy lifting, discrete fibres supporting a properly discontinuous group of deck transformations, and a well defined monodromy action. In this paper, we exhibit a minimal example where the total space fails to be Hausdorff, and we show that this single failure destroys all three pillars at once. Our example uses the line with k origins together with a simple map into a punctured disk whose fibre over the puncture consists of k indistinguishable points. In this setting path lifting and monodromy both fail, and yet the total space has trivial fundamental group even though none of the usual generalizations of covering spaces can accommodate it. This example illustrates in the simplest possible way why Hausdorff separation is essential to classical covering space theory.
item.dc:creator: Abhiram Sripat
